Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 09:24AM sandras_daughter wrote: Hi Claire and thanks so much for the reassurance.  We are in the process of setting an appt. with a major cancer center in Atlanta.  Truly everything that happened or didn't happen is water under the bridge.  They knew before she went in for her mastectomy the general size of her cancer, as well as her local biopsy results (grade 3, HER2+, so they knew beforehand that she had an aggressive cancer...).  If the 3 removed lymph nodes looked suspect when removed, it seems that would warrant additional node dissection at that time, instead of putting Mom through another surgery that it should have been known she would have to have, knowing she had an aggressive cancer.  The GS had her surgical biopsy results when she went for her follow up with him, but did not even mention additional surgery being indicated due to 3 nodes pos., nor did he mention the problem with the dye test or that he just took random nodes, nor did he mention any of the dye test problems to me immediately following her surgery.   Further, some 3 weeks after her surgery, he had received but had not sent her complete pathology report to the onco, just an report that said "pending."  Maybe not a total "botch" but I don't feel that he did right by Mom with his lack of disclosure to her, to me and lack of communication/follow up with her oncologist.  Further, I don't know whether it was up to the onco to tell the surgeon what he wanted done if a likely positive node was detected and that the decision to have a pathologist on standby to confirm cancer in a suspicious node so that Mom could avoid another surgery....  Like I said, I am new to all this, so maybe I am imagining a perfect world from a surgical/oncology standpoint....  I've just seemed to notice that others have had ax node dissections performed at the time of mastectomy, and seems like Mom's initial biopsy results would have strongly warranted it. Thanks so much for the reply.  As for the chemo, I definitely want good odds for my mom.  I learned a long time ago that she is hard-headed and will do or not do whatever she wants to do.  Hopefully, a cancer specialist who really takes the time to gently and compassionately explain and educate her towards making the right decision...
Posts.Title: Mistake made with my mom's surgery? sandras_daughter kcshreve

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 09:30AM sandras_daughter wrote: Hi meglove, I'd posted a reply to someone else before I saw your reply.  Based on what onco told us, gs removed 3 random s nodes.  The gs told me after her surgery that he removed 3 nodes that were enlarged and he felt sure they were pos.  Putting what he told me after surgery and what he told onco, it does seem odd that if he felt sure when he removed them that they were cancerous that he did not go ahead with the ax dissection, and never mentioned anything about it, nor about dye test problems....  Now, the fact that he called Mom within minutes of her getting home after visiting with the onco yesterday, trying to schedule another surgery for ax node dissection asap, it's pretty odd to me...
